snippet: The Shabab, which claimed responsibility for the deadly mall siege in Nairobi, Kenya, makes money through illegal endeavors and even employs a team of accountants.
abstract: Shabab, Somali militant Islamist group which claimed responsibility for the deadly mall siege in Nairobi, Kenya, shifts from one illegal business to another, drawing money from East Africa's underworld to finance attacks; officials in Africa and in the West are redoubling efforts to defeat or at least contain group--with watchful eye on its multiple sources of money--before its fighters can strike again in Kenya or even the United States.

byline.original: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and NICHOLAS KULISH
byline.contributor: Lydia Polgreen contributed reporting from New York, and Eric Schmitt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The Shabab, which claimed responsibility for the deadly mall siege in Nairobi, Kenya, makes money through illegal endeavors and even employs a team of accountants.

headline.main: Somali Militants Mixing Business and Terror
headline.print_headline: Somali Militants Mixing Business and Terror
